English: Come on, eat some potatoes, my son!
No!
Why [not], eat!
No, I don't want to eat
If that's so, eat popped maize
I won't eat popped maize either
If that's the case, slurp porridge
I don't like porridge
If that's so, eat rice

Kulung: make koŋ dʒa so tʃona t̪ʰoŋokǝ,
English: No! I already ate rice before I came
Okay, if that is the case, don't eat

Kulung: i:lei bu nus pǝkana ese koŋ badʒar kʰat̪o: minana mt̪ei kʰapsna badʒar meksa lamd̪umat̪ʰe,
English: One day elder brother woke up early, and, after having thought 'today I shall go to the market', he put on his clothes and walked to the market

Kulung: kʰikkana lampa khat̪tʃalo arko t̪elpika so badʒar kʰaip i:bum mislo t̪upat̪ʰe,
English: Thereafter, while walking along the road, he met someone from another village who was also going to market

Kulung: kʰikkana buʔa kʰuŋkǝ mis an ha:roi kʰat̪kǝ o:netʃʰoŋa lǝna t̪ǝt̪t̪ʰe,
English: Thereafter, elder brother asked that person, "Where are you going, my younger sibling?"

Kulung: kʰikkana netʃʰoʔa pika e buʔa o:mi kʰimt̪o o:tʃʰas t̪ukkʰa t̪una ʋa: 'kʰe:s kʰat̪o:kə buʔa lǝt̪ʰe',
English: Thereupon younger sibling said, 'Elder brother, I am going to buy a chicken because my children at home are ill'.

Kulung: kʰikkana buʔa pika e o:netʃʰoŋa amtʃʰatʃi kʰena kʰǝtʃi ui t̪uke pikana t̪ǝt̪t̪ʰe,
English: Thereafter, elder brother asked him, saying 'My younger sibling, which [limbs] of your children are hurting then?'.

Kulung: kʰikkana netʃʰoʔa pika buʔa somori tʃʰet̪o:no,
English: Then, younger sibling said, "I don't know the disease"

Kulung: an ha:pikəi e nana koŋ ha:pi ha:pikǝi,
English: Where are you from, oh elder sister, where am I from?

Kulung: ketʃʰe keiŋai e nana tʃʰelamd̪elam kʰapikǝi,
English: Was it us, oh elder sister, who cried, whilst we were on our way?
Long ago, in our language
Let's also sing songs  Otherwise [let's sing songs] at home

Kulung: ketʃʰe neni e nana u neni soŋ tʃʰu:at̪ʰe,
English: Long long ago, we(pi) talked, oh elder sister, whatever we talked about then has now happened
In our(pi) language, oh elder sister, we had our songs
Long ago, in our(pi) language
Let's also sing songs Otherwise [let's sing songs] in our(pi) house

Kulung: ketʃʰe ketʃʰe e nana i:bum pʰǝp t̪u:at̪ʰe,
English: Long long ago, oh elder sister, there was a grandfather, it is said
Sudulung, when his turn came, had to go here, it is said [in order to marry]
Long ago, in our language
Let's also sing songs  Otherwise, [let's sing songs] in our house
We are seeking the path
Otherwise, elder brother, we'll be singing in our(pi) language
Thus singing songs also in our(pi) language
If you don't like it, we start to scratch you up

Kulung: mo:bo mǝiam kulutʃʰa ʋatʃʰa lo bo: lo nu,
English: We(pi) are performing Mo:bo (name of a ritual), Kulung people, with chicks and pigs
We(pi) are all gathered, Kulung people, welcome
At the house down there, Kulung people, we once met
[our] grandmothers, Kulung people, Bairipco and Horem
With the hammer, Kulung people, the girls pound the nettle
[our] grandmother, Kulung people, is Ninam Ridum
The people who drink water, Kulung people, [are called] Tharu in our(pi) language
Our(pi) grandfather, Kulung people, is called Paru

Kulung: nam so appu kulutʃʰa ont̪o baip t̪ʰoŋake,
English: The sun has also risen, Kulung people, it is already that late
Our(pi) feet hurt, Kulung people, everyone's [legs] are stretched
The grandfathers, Kulung people, crossed Khuwolu

Kulung: mismi t̪ella kulutʃʰa t̪ʰoŋake t̪ambu lo,
English: By way of the people's villages, Kulung people, came Tambu

Kulung: pʰǝpatʃikǝ kulutʃʰa limbu lo kʰǝmbu lo,
English: our grandfathers, Kulung people, are Limbu and Khambu
[the ward] down at Muktho, Kulung people, has become Khamsido

Kulung: pʰǝpatʃikǝ kulutʃʰa tʃʰemsi lo t̪amsi lo,
English: [Our] grandfathers, Kulung people, are Chemsi and Tamsi
As a small star, Kulung people, Ninam has entered
[Our] grandfathers, Kulung people, came whilst killing birds
Potatoes and arum, Kulung people, all [of our people] have weeded them [i e  the fields]
[Our(pi)] rituals, Kulung people, our grandfathers peformed them
Our(pi) feet hurt, Kulung people, we pi all stretch our legs
[Our(pi)] rituals, Kulung people, we ask pi our ancestors
We(pi) plant maize, Kulung people, everyone has done the weeding
[Our(pi)] rituals, Kulung people, [our] ancestors performed them
Potatoes and arum, Kulung people, not cooked they are not done
[Our(pi)] rituals, Kulung people, not performed is bad
If we(pi) don't tie him up, Kulung people, the dog too will bite us pi
If we(pi) don't perform [the rituals], Kulung people, we(pi) shall be obstructed
May [our(pi)] heirs, Kulung people, also know us(pi)

Kulung: ninamma lo kulutʃʰa tʃara lo ket̪inu,
English: May Ninam, Kulung people, and our land protect us(pi)

Kulung: huktʃi kela kulutʃʰa siŋtʃʰa so ət̪ake,
English: The winds blew, Kulung people, branches were also broken
Now, Kulung people, our(pe) song is finished

Kulung: rid̪um keia masamno hənna keia lamamke,
English: We(pi) don't want to lose our(pi) rituals  Now we(pi) are searching for them

Kulung: u soŋ keia tʃʰet̪amno рʰәра t̪ət̪amke,
English: What we(pi) don't know, we(pi) ask our(pi) grandfathers
We(pi) dig with our(pi) hoes the fibre and fern fields of our(pi) grandfathers
Now we make an end to ourpi talk

Kulung: ketʃʰe kei kʰo:loŋai pu boro t̪oŋkə t̪u:ikə,
English: Long ago, we(pi) were all like snakes and frogs
Wearing sack clothes, we(pi) became human beings
In our(pi) village, the girls spin on spindles
Today we(pi) make a song in our(pi) Kulung language
Elder brothers, elder sisters, we(pi) perform our(pi) rituals

Kulung: irid̪um mamməmo buʔa naʔa ŋeiʔa t̪ʰaijake,
English: We(pi) are hindered by not performing ourpi rituals, elder brothers, elder sisters

Kulung: tʃʰemsi lo t̪amsi lo ipʰaptʃa bei lipʰu ʋestʃit̪ʰe,
English: Chemsi and Tamsi, our(pi) grandfathers strapped on their bow and arrow, it is said
Thereafter they all knew our(pi) rites, it is said
Elder brothers, elder sisters, we(pi) perform our(pi) rituals

Kulung: irid̪um mamməmo buʔa naʔa ŋeila t̪ʰəijake,
English: We(pi) are hindered by not performing our(pi) rituals, elder brothers, elder sisters
We(pi) ask ourpi rites and rituals from our(pi) grandfathers and grandmothers

Kulung: irid̪um mət̪o kʰaiam kʰo:loʔa ihu sət̪amke,
English: We(pi) are going to perform our(pi) rites and we shall all stretch out our(pi) hands
Elder brothers, elder sisters, we(pi) perform our(pi) rituals

Kulung: irid̪um mamməmo buʔa naʔa ŋeila t̪haijake,
English: We(pi) are hindered by not performing our(pi) rituals, elder brothers, elder sisters

Kulung: o:ninka bud̪d̪hi bahad̪ur kulutʃʰa o:po:sko tʃʰapsko tʃʰeskamke            ,
English: My name is Buddhi Bahādur Kulung  My birthplace and place of registration is Cheskäm

Kulung: irid̪um ʋat̪am papa t̪ət̪am kʰo:loʔa lesamke,
English: We(pi) ask ourpi rites and rituals slowly from our(pi) grand-fathers, [so that] we(pi) shall all know them
Elder brothers, elder sisters, we(pi) perform our(pi) rituals

Kulung: irid̪um mamməmo buʔa naʔa ŋeiʔa t̪ʰəijake,
English: We(pi) are hindered by not performing our(pi) rituals, elder brothers, elder sisters
From once being big [our song] has become small
You have heard the song we(pi) have sung, now the song is finished
Elder brothers, elder sisters, we(pi) perform our(pi) rituals

Kulung: irid̪um mamməmo buʔa naʔa ŋeila t̪ʰəijake,
English: We(pi) are hindered by not performing our(pi) rituals, elder brothers, elder sisters
From the peak of Chemsin, Mãmerku could be seen

Kulung: it̪oŋt̪o bə:nam ikaŋka huʋa saraŋai pat̪ake,
English: On our head was a headstrap, and from ourpi teeth a lot of sweat would drip
We(pi) plant maize plants and weed them in Vaiśākh (April/May)

Kulung: it̪elpi keia d̪umo lo d̪umo d̪ukʋa so t̪əiamke,
English: In our(pi) village, wepi incur a lot of misery too

Kulung: huktʃi so kela sintʃha so ət̪ake,
English: The winds were blowing and the branches were broken

Kulung: it̪elpi imi d̪umo lo d̪umo singas so mət̪ake,
English: In our(pi) village, ourpi fodder is always finished
We(pi) cook raksi, we(pi) all lift up [the cooking pan]

Kulung: itʃʰatʃi mla:gi itʃastʃi mla:gi si:tʃʰo so let̪amke,
English: For our(pi) children, for our(pi) grandchildren, we(pi) also plant trees

Kulung: koŋ tʃi:ma t̪u:olo o:pa si:a kʰat̪a,
English: When I was young, my father died
When I was full grown, my brother went off to the army

Kulung: o:tʃʰa t̪aie pikt̪o saraŋ o:ma kʰapa,
English: Saying 'My child will return', my mother wept bitterly
We(pi) spin threads on a small piece of wood

Kulung: hənna kei tʃʰamtʃi ləija ikuluŋkə riŋpika,
English: Now we(pi) sing songs in our(pi) Kulung language

Kulung: so:go so kʰat̪ja kʰo:loŋai lam ləija,
English: We(pi) go to the jungle, we(pi) all seek [the way]
Now we(pi) sing a song in our(pi) language

Kulung: mo:bo so məiam ʋa:tʃʰa lo bo: lo nu,
English: We(pi) perform Mobo with chicks and pigs
We(pi) have all met again, elder brothers, welcome
We(pi) cook potatoes, they don't cook in the cooking pan,

Kulung: it̪elpi imi so:go so mand̪i so:mtʃʰakə tʃʰu:noke,
English: In our(pi) village, without our(pi) forest, there can be no human beings
We(pi) plant potatoes, in Āṣāḍh (June/July) we(pi) dig them up
For fertiliser, we(pi) push them together with the leaves [in the ground]
One pours ground maize in a cooking pot
Then, having poured ground maize [in the cooking pot], it cooks
A little buckwheat has to be added
Then yeast must be added
Having poured yeast into [the cooking pot], one ferments it [the maize] in a bamboo basket
Thereafter, having fermented [the maize] in a bamboo basket, [the maize] will be fermented
Thereafter, one pours [the maize] into a jug *
Having poured [the maize] into a jug, one drinks the beer

Kulung: kʰikkana nurma d̪uŋum kʰi:amka msipne raksi ŋi:am,
English: Afterwards, from the husk of the unfiltered beer that one has drunk, one cooks [i e  distils] raksi
